back through both pieces of fabric and through the loop already on hook repeat from * maintaining firm even gauge hexi construction set up make a magic_ring or alternatively chain 4 and slip_stitch in the 4th chain from hook to create ring r1 in ring chain 3 counts as first double_crochet 2 double_crochet *chain 2 3 double_crochet* repeat 4 times and end by joining a half_double_crochet to the 3rd markers placed 3 r3 chain 3 2 double_crochet in same space *skip 3 double_crochet cluster work 3 double_crochet in space between clusters edge cluster made skip 3 double_crochet cluster in next marked corner space work 3 double_crochet chain 2 3 double_crochet * repeat between * * around to the initial chain space 3 double_crochet in initial chain space join with half_double_crochet to the 3rd chain of the initial turning chain 6- 3dc edge clusters 6- corner spaces 3dc ch2 3dc 1- joining half_double_crochet shift each marker up into the new chain 2 space of each corner made r4+ for following row start each row with a chain 3 2 double_crochet in same space then work an edge cluster 3 double_crochet into each space along the edge of the hexagon work corner clusters into each marked corner space moving the marker up as you go end each round with a half_double_crochet in the 3rd chain of the turning chain half cardi continue working r4 until your hexagon folds into an appropriately sized sleeve you can determine the size of your half cardi by measuring around your arm or a favorite top to find your chosen sleeve size in inches i usually choose between 20-24 inches around this means that when one edge of your hexagon measures roughly your sleeve size ex 20 inches you will end by joining in the round with a half_double_crochet then measure it against your body you can use locking stitch markers to help hold the corners together try on the sleeve and make sure it is comfortable if it is correct make sure you put wrong sides together and seam up the top of
